description: standing stylized female figure with claws on feet; tan/orange body with large breasts, rounded stomach and elongated vagina; peacock-like tail feathers with skulls; three-dimensional face with smiling mouth with red lips; red spots on cheeks, chin and between eyes; red line on nose; light blue ground; white painted deep frame with silver painted liner
inscription: on back, in brown: 5616 Glenwood / Chicago, Ill.
markings: on back: Art Institute of Chicago label
signed: LRC, in black: T. HALKIN / 57 | on back, in black: T. Halkin | on back, in brown: Harpy
text: Chicago native Ted Halkin served as a medic on Iwo Jima during World War II and spent the war years administering to soldiers who suffered devastating trauma. His work after the war often cast mythological creatures as allegorical figures of suffering and redemption. Here he uses the harpy, a creature from Greek and Roman mythology, as a threatening agent of torture for those who caused pain and death during the war.
title: The Harpy
